pageProps.contentHtml:
Runge's theorem

Let T={z∈C | ∣z∣=1}\T = \set{z \in \C \st \abs{z} = 1}T={z∈C∣∣z∣=1} and let K⊊TK \subsetneq \TK⊊T be a compact proper subset.

  1. Show that there is a sequence of polynomials Pn(z)P_n\p{z}Pn​(z) such that Pn(z)→z‾P_n\p{z} \to \conj{z}Pn​(z)→z uniformly on KKK.
  2. Show that there is no sequence of polynomials Pn(z)P_n\p{z}Pn​(z) for which Pn(z)→z‾P_n\p{z} \to \conj{z}Pn​(z)→z uniformly on T\TT.
Solution.

  1. This follows immediately from Runge's theorem since C∖K\C \setminus KC∖K has one unbounded connected component. Explicitly, this is because z‾=1z\conj{z} = \frac{1}{z}z=z1​ on T\TT, so it suffices to show that we can approximate 1z\frac{1}{z}z1​ on KKK by polynomials.

    First, observe that we may "push" poles as follows:

    1z−z0=1(z−z1)−(z0−z1)=1z−z1∑n=0∞(z0−z1z−z1)n,\frac{1}{z - z_0} = \frac{1}{\p{z - z_1} - \p{z_0 - z_1}} = \frac{1}{z - z_1} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \p{\frac{z_0 - z_1}{z - z_1}}^n,z−z0​1​=(z−z1​)−(z0​−z1​)1​=z−z1​1​n=0∑∞​(z−z1​z0​−z1​​)n,

    and this will converge uniformly as long as z1z_1z1​ is chosen such that ∣z0−z1∣≤12∣z−z1∣\abs{z_0 - z_1} \leq \frac{1}{2} \abs{z - z_1}∣z0​−z1​∣≤21​∣z−z1​∣, e.g., with ∣z0−z1∣≤13d(z0,K)=r\abs{z_0 - z_1} \leq \frac{1}{3}d\p{z_0, K} = r∣z0​−z1​∣≤31​d(z0​,K)=r, since

    ∣z−z1∣≥∣z−z0∣−∣z0−z1∣≥2r  ⟹  ∣z0−z1z−z1∣≤12.\abs{z - z_1} \geq \abs{z - z_0} - \abs{z_0 - z_1} \geq 2r \implies \abs{\frac{z_0 - z_1}{z - z_1}} \leq \frac{1}{2}.∣z−z1​∣≥∣z−z0​∣−∣z0​−z1​∣≥2r⟹∣∣​z−z1​z0​−z1​​∣∣​≤21​.

    In other words, given a rational function with a pole only at z0z_0z0​, we can approximate it uniformly by rational functions with a single pole in B(z0,r)B\p{z_0, r}B(z0​,r), so by iterating this construction, we can move the poles as far away as we want. In particular, we can approximate 1z\frac{1}{z}z1​ uniformly on KKK by a function with a single pole arbitrarily far away from KKK. In particular, we can prescribe the pole to have ∣z0∣≥2sup⁡z∈K ∣z∣\abs{z_0} \geq 2 \sup_{z \in K}\,\abs{z}∣z0​∣≥2supz∈K​∣z∣. Then

    1z−z0=−1z011−zz0=−1z0∑n=0∞(zz0)n\frac{1}{z - z_0} = -\frac{1}{z_0} \frac{1}{1 - \frac{z}{z_0}} = -\frac{1}{z_0} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \p{\frac{z}{z_0}}^nz−z0​1​=−z0​1​1−z0​z​1​=−z0​1​n=0∑∞​(z0​z​)n

    converges uniformly on KKK, which completes the proof.

  2. Observe that for any polynomial p(z)=∑k=1nakzkp\p{z} = \sum_{k=1}^n a_k z_kp(z)=∑k=1n​ak​zk​, we have

    2π=∣∫T∣z∣2 dz∣=∣∫Tzz‾ dz∣=∣∫Tz(z‾−p(z)) dz+∫Tzp(z) dz∣=∣∫Tz(z‾−p(z)) dz∣(Cauchy’s theorem)≤∫T∣z‾−p(z)∣ dz≤2π∥z‾−p∥L∞.\begin{aligned} 2\pi &= \abs{\int_\T \abs{z}^2 \,\diff{z}} \\ &= \abs{\int_\T z\conj{z} \,\diff{z}} \\ &= \abs{\int_\T z\p{\conj{z} - p\p{z}} \,\diff{z} + \int_\T zp\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \\ &= \abs{\int_\T z\p{\conj{z} - p\p{z}} \,\diff{z}} && \p{\text{Cauchy's theorem}} \\ &\leq \int_\T \abs{\conj{z} - p\p{z}} \,\diff{z} \\ &\leq 2\pi \norm{\conj{z} - p}_{L^\infty}. \end{aligned}2π​=∣∣​∫T​∣z∣2dz∣∣​=∣∣​∫T​zzdz∣∣​=∣∣​∫T​z(z−p(z))dz+∫T​zp(z)dz∣∣​=∣∣​∫T​z(z−p(z))dz∣∣​≤∫T​∣z−p(z)∣dz≤2π∥z−p∥L∞​.​​(Cauchy’s theorem)​

    In particular, ∥z‾−p∥L∞≥1\norm{\conj{z} - p}_{L^\infty} \geq 1∥z−p∥L∞​≥1 for any polynomial, so z‾\conj{z}z cannot be approximated by a polynomial uniformly on all of T\TT.
